page.title: 16GUMLEY HOUSE SCHOOL
page.content: Built by Mr John Gumley - a famous glassmaker - in about 1700.It remained a private house until 1841 when it was sold to Madame de Bonnault D'hout, the foundress of the Faithful Companions of Jesus whose main object was the education of the poor. A boarding school was also set up for wealthy students to subsidise the original school. During the 19th century the number of pupils increased to nearly 100. The school was recognised by the Board of Education in 1922. The boarding school was closed in 1939 at the start of the second world war. It reopened in 1945 but the number of boarders decreased and it was formally closed in 1968. By 1959 Gumley was a 2-form entry grammar school. It expanded to 3-form and eventually 4-form entry. In 1976 it became a 6-form entry comprehensive school.
